fields.description:
It seems that sometimes the JVM is terminated midway through Clover writing coverage and the alternate file does not have the full coverage data.

One way to mitigate this problem is to force a full flush after every test finishes. That way the 2nd last coverage file will always be complete (for directed flushing and discounting multithreaded tests).
fields.summary: Clover coverage files sometimes get corrupted

fields.description:
As documented in http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CLOVER/clover-report#clover-report-Columns and blogged about here: http://blogs.atlassian.com/2009/09/express_yourself_with_clover_el/

the addition of an expression element in the clover-columns adds columns into the Clover HTML report.  It does not seem to have that same affect on the Clover XML report.

It would also be nice if the clover2:check goal, or a similar new goal, could take into consideration the new columns and somehow fail on violation during a post-site phase, since any new columns introduced via Clover EL are only done during the report generation in the site phase.

So, if we defined:

<expression title="crap" max="6" scope="method">complexity^2 * ((1 - %coveredElements/100)^3) + complexity</expression>

the build could still generate both the XML and HTML reports, if requested, but also fail during a post-site validation of sorts, since a method was found to violate the maximum crap value.

Hopefully, the XML report could look similar to what Sebastian Bergmann has included in his PHPUnit coverage report.  http://sebastian-bergmann.de/archives/877-CRAP-in-PHPUnit-3.5.html

The XML output of those reports contains elements and attributes that would seem to be based on the Clover XML report, but now include additional attributes such as the "crap" calculations:


<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?> 
<coverage generated="1325871303">
 <project timestamp="1325871303">
 <file name="C:\p4\OR-STMARING-D1\p4-wdpro\Projects\NGE\Sites\pep\main\src\application\controllers\actions\helpers/AddCompositeToCart.php">
 <class name="Default_Controller_Action_Helper_AddCompositeToCart" namespace="global" fullPackage="Default.Controller.Action.Helper">
  <metrics methods="5" coveredmethods="5" conditionals="0" coveredconditionals="0" statements="57" coveredstatements="54" elements="62" coveredelements="59" /> 
  </class>
  <line num="0" type="stmt" count="1" /> 
  <line num="63" type="method" name="init" crap="1" count="4" />

fields.description:
This is occurring in both the official 3.1.2 and the latest snapshot sent. When restarting IDEA 11 after having enabled and run tests while Clover was installed, shutting down and restarting IDEA will hang on the 'splash' screen. Killing it and restarting will get IDEA going again, and it will complain about having corrupted indexes. The indexes rebuild and you can continue working, but then rebooting again will have the same issue. Disabling Clover resolves the issue.

I looked through the system logs and found the log attached, which seems to be related.
fields.summary: Clover hangs IDEA 11 on boot after a restart
Clover-for-Intellij incorrectly reports a new version is available even if the current version is the latests

fields.description:
My specific issue comes with the @SuppressWarnings({"fallthrough"}) annotation that is added by clover's instrumentation.

In the same java file, we are importing the following from the findbugs library:

import edu.umd.cs.findbugs.annotations.*;

The above package also contains a SuppressWarnings annotation.  Thus, when the instrumented class is compiled, I'm greeted with this error:


/tmp/clover9189767877125005725.tmp/search/smartscope/SmartSearchData.java:42: reference to SuppressWarnings is ambiguous, both class edu.umd.cs.findbugs.annotations.SuppressWarnings in edu.umd.cs.findbugs.annotations and class java.lang.SuppressWarnings in java.lang match


This could all be resolved if clover used @java.lang.SuppressWarnings({"fallthrough"}) instead of just the annotation without the package specification.  

I assume other bugs like this exist as well involving other classes/annotations that clover adds, but this is the one we have encountered. 

Just an FYI, I'm using clover 3.1.0, however, I assume this issue stands in all clover versions.
fields.summary: When instrumenting code, fully qualified class names should be used for Classes and Annotations being added to prevent ambiguous references.

fields.description:
I am using clover 3.1.0, jdk 1.6 and maven 3.0.3

I have a test that takes a parameter as input, and the report is generated using 

mvn clover2:setup test clover2:aggregate clover2:clover

In report, the testmethod is showing up as  $testMethod.qualifiedName

Please see the attached picture for more details. When I click the link on that particular method,  it is giving me a directory listing instead of actual source.
fields.summary: Testng test with parameters shows $testMethod.qualifiedName as test name in reports

fields.description:
Hi Everyone,

We have a multi-module project setup which we are trying to integrate with clover. The clover coverage and the reports look good. Our unit tests are written in TestNG and the integration tests are in a wrapper framework of TestNG. The problem we are facing right now is that we are seeing a broken link like $testMethod.qualifiedName for the integration test classes. We found that an external descriptor can be configured for detecting advanced test cases like this. But couldn't find much documentation on this.
We configured an external descriptor as follows 

<project name="Clover Report"> 
    <clover-setup>
		<testsources dir="src/test/java">
			<testclass>
			  <testmethod name="runTest*"/>
			</testclass>
		  </testsources>
	</clover-setup>
	
	<target name="current">
        <clover-report>
			<current outfile="clover_html" title="My Project" summary="true">
				<format type="html"/>   
			</current>
        </clover-report>
    </target>
	
</project>

And we pointed to this xml file using the command line argument -Dmaven.clover.reportDescriptor
We get an exception like this

[ERROR] Failed to execute goal com.atlassian.maven.plugins:maven-clover2-plugin:3.1.0:clover (test) on project myprojectname: Execution test of goal com.atlassian.maven.plugins:maven-clover2-plugin:3.1.0:clover failed: com.atlassian.clover.registry.NoSuchRegistryException: Clover registry file "/myprojectname/.clover/clover3_1_0.db" does not exist, cannot be read or is a directory.

And the build fails. 
Can anyone please provide some insight on how to configure an external descriptor file properly and also how to configure the advanced test cases with some examples.

Thanks !
fields.summary: Advanced Test case detection configuration

fields.description:
see support case https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CLV-5734

We could pretty easily add {{visibility="public|package|protected|private"}} attribute to {{<line type="method" ... >}} elements, which would allow the user to ignore methods of certain visibility. I think the addition of this attribute would cause minimal disruption to existing consumers of clover.xml. Note that clover.xml doesn't group statements by method, so this wouldn't allow statement coverage to be filtered by method visibility. You would only be able to calculate method-entry coverage for a given visibility.
fields.summary: add more information to Clover's xml reports

fields.description:
Some customers would like to use a continuous testing methodology in their development effort. Currently, they are using Infinitest (http://infinitest.github.com/) as a plugin to Eclipse for automatic test execution on save. Infinitest does work with Clover, however, it does not execute the optimized tests.

It would seem to be very simple for Clover to have a builder plugin for Eclipse that will run the optimized tests on every save of a source file, and present a statusbar indication of success like Infinitest.
fields.summary: Continuous Testing Support

fields.description:
Some customers use JBoss Drools for their projects. Nowadays, Clover does not know how to instrument compiled DRL files or annotate them in the Eclipse DRL editor (provided by the JBoss Tools plugin for DRL files).

They have JUnit tests that load and execute against tests within their DRL files. 
It would be very, very helpful if there was a way to have Clover instrument the compiled DRL files and annotate the DRL editor.

Please consider adding the functionality to Eclipse.
fields.summary: Add Drools Support

fields.description:
It would be really nice to be able to take two runs of software and compare which lines got executed using Clover.

I do see a PERL Script available at:
http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=34519&tstart=0
but I have no idea how to run PERL. I stay 100% Java for many reasons.

Running twice and comparing is not useful for just code coverage. It is also very useful for code development. I build walking robots and often I'll run two different things on the robot that are 80% the same. One will work well, the other will work poorly. So then I try to figure out what differences are causing the difference in performance.

It would be really useful to run one, then run the other, then see which code that got executed was the same and which code was different.

You could use a set of colors for the comparison. One color for first run only, one for second run only, one for both runs, one color for neither run.

Please consider it, especially if it's not too hard to implement. I think there are lots of people who would like to know differences in code coverage between various runs or settings.
fields.summary: Compare two runs with Clover

fields.description:
When the Clover Groovy plugin was developed, only the standard Maven Groovy compiler (GMaven) was targeted. 

The plugin wasn't tested against the Maven Groovy Eclipse compiler, so this compiler is incompatible at the moment.

It would be great if the Clover Groovy plugin supported the Maven Groovy Eclipse compiler, because GMaven is [becoming obsolete|http://docs.codehaus.org/display/GMAVEN/Home], and the Maven Groovy Eclipse compiler usage is becoming more popular.
fields.summary: Support for Maven Groovy Eclipse compiler

fields.description: When selecting Run or Debug As in Eclipse on a Clover enabled project, Clover measures the coverage. This makes debugging difficult because it adds an extra method call after each statement. It would be better if coverage was only given when Run or Debug with Clover As were selected.
fields.summary: Run and Debug As in Eclipse should run without Clover coverage

fields.description:
I am trying to start a GAE run configuration in IDEA 10.5 - after compilation and the web artifact being built, the process simply fails to start, with no errors.  I uninstalled the plug-in and the process once again starts correctly.

I also attempted to create a plain Java Application run configuration to start the process instead and this also fails with the same issue.  The GAE libraries are pulled in as module libraries, via a Maven POM.  I'm not sure if this is linked, but there definitely seems to be a problem with Run configurations when the main Java class being run is located in an external library, rather than being part of the project code-base.  I've checked the IDEA logs and no errors are thrown.  The plain Java Application run configuration had the following settings:

Main Class: com.google.appengine.tools.development.DevAppServerMain
VM Parameters: -Dappengine.sdk.root=<sdk_root> -javaagent:<sdk_root>/lib/agent/appengine-agent.jar
Program Parameters: --disable_update_check <war_file_location>
Working Directory: <sdk_root>
fields.summary: Can't Use "Google App Engine" Run Configuration in IDEA 10.5 when Clover Plug-in is Installed

fields.description:
In the [Clover download page|http://www.atlassian.com/software/clover/CloverDownloadCenter.jspa] it should be possible to download the Clover for Maven 2 plugin jar/zip, and the link should be something like:

http://www.atlassian.com/software/clover/downloads/binary/clover-ant-3.1.0.zip (that's for Ant, of course)

However, the "Clover for Maven 2" link is linking to the Installation Guide, not to the {{jar}} or {{zip}} download:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CLOVER/Clover-for-Maven+2+Installation+Guide

Which is incorrect as well, as the current Installation Guide is located at:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CLOVER/Clover-for-Maven+2+and+3+Installation+Guide
fields.summary: Wrong link on Clover download page

fields.description:
Clover is a great tool, especially the "contributing tests" and test optimization features are very nice. However, wouldn't it be cool as well to integrate an automatic test runner? I think this would be a great addon: modify code while Clover automatically (and continuously) runs related tests.

I'd be happy about any sort of discussion or feedback on the idea.
fields.summary: Add a continuous test runner for Eclipse

fields.description:
I've got the dev build from CLOV-1004, which worked for Intellij 10.3 but since I upgraded to 10.5.1, neither the latest public rev (3.1.0.v20110608114626-dev) nor the dev version of the plugin from CLOV-1004 works.

In the projects view, it looks like the code is instrumented.  But after I run a test, no coverage information is displayed.  When I explicitly update the clover database, nothing is updated.  The "Test Runs" view behaves as if I never ran a test.
fields.summary: Coverage data not showing up in Intellij

fields.description:
When running <clover-report/> in html format, it does not clear the previous report's html files. This is a problem when running multiple builds over time because the report directory continuously grows and grows.

And then, this can be an issue when tied into Bamboo, due to how Bamboo stores it's artifacts (copies the entire report directory over to the server). 

Although it's easy to work around this by deleting the clover-report/current directory before a new build, it would be nice if this limitation was mentioned in the documentation OR the functionality of deleting the previous report was added to either the {{<clover-clean/>}} target or to the {{<clover-report/>}} target.
fields.summary: Clover html reports don't wipe previous reports/html files

fields.description: Clover ships with easy integration with Ant and Maven. It would be nice to extend this support to the Gradle build system.
fields.summary: Clover integration with Gradle

fields.description:
CAC describes using [Clover Command Line Tools|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CLOVER/Clover+Command+Line+Tools], but users are left wondering where to download it from.

I've been telling them they can download the Clover-for-Ant zip, and use the clover.jar from the lib directory. If we could indicate something like this, provide a download link, etc, that would be very helpful!
fields.summary: Indicate where to download Clover command line tools from

fields.description:
This happens either if no java class was found for instrumentation or if they were all excluded.
Clover then reports a negative coverage of -100%.

To my mind, this is not correct : strictly speaking, if no java class has to be tested for coverage, there is no relevant coverage value (I guess it is what the -100% means) but check should be OK.
fields.summary: clover2:check fails with negative coverage if no class to instrument

fields.description: It should accept -Dclover.flushpolicy and -Dclover.flushinterval
fields.summary: Clover Ant listener does not accept flush policy or interval settings from the command line

fields.description:
Classes containing enums are failing to compile, and display the error "Error: CloverException: unexpected token: <<enum name>>" or "Error: CloverException: unexpected token enum".
Have attached example failing code with company name and details stripped out.
I've marked this as a blocker as I can't get the plugin to work at all. I thought it may have been clashing with the scala plugin but I have disabled that and there are still problems.
fields.summary: Intellij 10.5 with clover 3.1 is throwing: "Error: CloverException: unexpected token" for enums

fields.description:
Log4j's interface has changed a bit since we coded support for it. It would work but our initialisation code looks for the wrong method signature

clover.org.apache.log4j.Logger.log(clover.org.apache.log4j.Level, Object, Throwable)

but should be looking for

clover.org.apache.log4j.Category.log(clover.org.apache.log4j.Priority, Object, Throwable)
fields.summary: Clover's Log4J handling is broken

fields.description:
In a Clover history report, a graph of code metrics is included by default, which includes columns for Total Files, Complexity, Lines, Total Packages, and NC Lines.  All of these numbers are calculated from non-test code.  We would like a way to have test code (JUnit) count towards these metrics without having to perform a separate run of all of our tests with Clover to turn off the automatic detection of test classes in order to get these numbers.

We would like this feature to help identify when the exponential growth of test code starts to outstrip the linear growth of our codebase.  Since test classes do not contribute to the metrics that you collect, this phenomena is invisible to us.
fields.summary: Option to include LOC contributed by test classes to total count of LOC

fields.description: When building an historical report of Clover coverage metrics, it would be nice to be able to generate a chart of the history of the number of JUnit tests executed/passed/failed.  These numbers are already displayed for the current build, but we would like to see a history of them.
fields.summary: Metrics for JUnit tests passed/failed in Clover history report
Support Intellij 10.5
Ensure Clover support Groovy 1.7 & 1.8
Support JDK 1.7 language features

fields.description:
If a test run takes longer than the refresh period for coverage, intermediate coverage data may be loaded (depending on flush settings) and the final coverage data is not subsequently loaded.

The quick solution is to hold off loading coverage while ever a coverage.db.liverec file is present.

The longer term solution will be a combination of:
* track the last modified stamps and file sizes for coverage recording file 
* implement an undo framework for all recording files so that intermediate coverage loads can be undone and updated coverage can be appended
fields.summary: Clover-for-Eclipse may load intermediate coverage results and not load subsequent coverage updates
Ternary clauses never executed still get coverage
Inline assignments within while loop clause get no coverage

fields.description:
It would be great to be able to report code coverage statistics per developer by tying into the SCM of a given project, something similar to what the maven blame:blame plugin (http://maven-blame-plugin.codehaus.org/) attempts to do or what the stat-svn project does (http://wiki.statsvn.org/).

I realize this functionality could be abused, however, my development team would love to see their own code statistics in order to better track their own quality of work.  Code coverage is one aspect of this which we cannot accurately report on at a developer level.

Primary use case: What percentage of code introduced by developer A is covered via tests?
fields.summary: Code Coverage Per Developer

fields.description:
(SEN-656820 :)

Silly question perhaps but I couldn't find anything in the documentation. Does Clover log operations (not test results) to anywhere other than STDERR/STDOUT? Is there a way to increase the verbosity of any such logging?

I have a Clover that's stuck spawning one thread at a time that sucks up 100% CPU (judging by PIDs, though, it's reaping the thread that's taking up 100% CPU and then creating another one). I've tried debugging it with some standard stuff but nothing obvious. A logfile telling me quite what's going on would be helpful. Hopefully this is just something that's missing in the documentation.

(We have a 'kill -3' and STDOUT log if you're interested in the hang as well.)

Thanks for your time,

David B Harris
fields.summary: Is it possible to log to a file and/or increase the verbosity of logging?

fields.description:
I select either the filter button in the coverage panel or go via the project settings (same either way) to get to the clover setting dialog. I select the 3rd tab (Contexts) and check the check-boxes 'catch bosy' and 'property methods'. The boxes become checked but the Apply button remains disabled (this is the main issue).

I add a new custom context - and the Apply button is enabled.

I click apply and the check boxes all reset back to their un-set state. The custom context remains.
fields.summary: Cannot select contexts in IDEA 10.0.2

fields.description:
If Parametrized tests are run with Junit Parameterized test runner, the reports (html, xml) only show multiple executions of the same test, but no indication of which instance of the test (and which parameter set) was executed. 
This would be important, since depending on the parameters coverage may vary quite a lot. 
It would be great to see something like the following in the reports:
{code}
org.someorg.MyParameterizedTest.test[0]
org.someorg.MyParameterizedTest.test[1]
etc.
{code}
fields.summary: Make parametrized tests identifiyable in clover database and reports

fields.description:
This applies to clover-ant. Passing build.compiler property from command-line or via a nested property in an <ant> call freezes this property in the executed (sub-) project. As far as I can tell, clover-setup attempts to substitute build.compiler with its own source code parser, which is then delegated to the actual build.compiler -- this fails if build.compiler is frozen and no code is preprocessed.

A potential fix is to replace the frozen property (ANT's Project has two methods for setting properties, can't recall their name now, but one of them is able to override a property, even if it's already bound to a value). Another fix is to fail the build if it is detected that clover-setup has been executed, but build.property is not replaced.
fields.summary: Forced build.compiler property confuses clover, no parsed code is generated.

fields.description:
see support case https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CLV-5576 and forum post http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257357810

the solution is to simply exclude this file when building the clover.jar
fields.summary: Clover's embedding of GSON brings in "assembly-descriptor.xml" into clover.jar which causes problems for ejbdoclet, others

fields.description:
We are using the Clover-Ant-Task on our Bamboo-Server.
This is creating rather large artifacts (initial about 8GB). The main problem is that this artifacts keep on growing from build to build. Last time they reached about 77GB (the server went out of diks space at this point).

Ther should be a way to effectivly reduce the needed space for the generated artifacts.
fields.summary: Clover produces huge and growing coverage data

fields.description:
Clover is one big FAIL when it is invoked within an <parallel/> task either through <clover-instr/> or <javac/>

Effectively it tries to overwrite databases and the last compile to finish will fail (on Windows) because of file locking.

At the very least we should warn that parallel compilation is not supported.
fields.summary: Clover doesn't support parallel compilation in Ant

fields.description:
Run Optimized button does not run any tests.
It gives a proper balloon notification with the number of tests to be run but then it runs none.
It is probably caused by yet another change in test runner in Idea.

Bad news is that when I tried to reproduce it on recent Idea9 it also failed.

The solution would require looking at how Idea runs it's test this time and find some hack to hook into the process - there is no clear API for that.
fields.summary: No tests run with Test Optimization
When a method annotated with @Test(expected = ...) is overridden, the overriding method should not expect an exception.

In the unit tests I test only the happy scenario, this exception is never thrown during my tests. The clover code coverage is still 100% for this method. fields.description:
We are using clover 3.0.2 using the maven-clover2-plugin and noticed it doesn't support coverage per package like the ant plugin supports.  We would rather not have to call out to ant to run coverage reports as maven gives you good support for this already using the maven plugins.  I think a lot of people would benefit from this feature.  See below for how it is done with the ant.

<target name="check-coverage" depends="try-clover">
<echo message="Override coverage check for module: ${clover.module.name }"/>
<clover-check initstring="${clover.db.dir}/${clover.module.name}.db"
haltOnFailure="true"
target="85"
methodTarget="90"
statementTarget="85"
conditionalTarget="75">
<package name="com.company.gobbles" target="85"/>
<package name="com.company.gobbles.backend" target="70"/>
<package name="com.company.gobbles.cache" target="92"/>
<package name="com.company.gobbles.cache.analyzer" target="0"/>

But with maven we can only set targets for the ones below:

<plugin>
<groupId>com.atlassian.maven.plugins</groupId>
<artifactId>maven-clover2-plugin</artifactId>
<version>${clover.version}</version>
<configuration>
<license>${clover.license}</license>

<targetPercentage>${coverage.target}</targetPercentage>

<methodPercentage>${coverage.target.method}</methodPercentage>

<statementPercentage>${coverage.target.statement}</statementPercentage>

<conditionalPercentage>${coverage.target.conditional}</conditionalPercentage>
</configuration>
<executions>
<execution>
<id>clover-setup</id>
<phase>generate-resources</phase>
<goals>
<goal>setup</goal>
</goals>
</execution>
<execution>
<id>clover-verify</id>
<phase>verify</phase>
<goals>
<goal>check</goal>
<goal>clover</goal>
</goals>
</execution>
</executions>
</plugin>
</plugin>

Please consider putting this in your next release.

Thanks,
Jay
fields.summary: Maven Clover Plugin to support package coverage

fields.description:
There is at least one known issue with the version of plexus used:

{quote}
This is an issue in plexus-resources:1.0-alpha-4 and its classpath resource locator which relied on a bug in the class loaders in Maven 2. Please update the plugin to use the latest plexus-resources version.
{quote}

The work around for this, for anyone wishing to use Maven3 with Clover2 is:

bq. Independently of an update to the Clover Plugin, you can make the build work right now by overriding the plugin dependency in the POM yourself.


There may be other problems as well.

NB: Maven3 is currently in beta and not one of the versions supported by the Clover2 maven plugin.
fields.summary: Make the maven-clover2-plugin support Maven3

fields.description:
*Problem*

Copied from: https://studio.plugins.atlassian.com/browse/CLMVN-132

check out sample project from svn: https://indoorsdog-sandbox.googlecode.com/svn/insuchaworld/clover-bug-example
repo root: https://indoorsdog-sandbox.googlecode.com/svn

place your "clover.license" file at project root

run "mvn clean verify site"

look in /target/classes, see /groverconfigxxx/instrumentation.ser file

it really shouldn't be there, that area is for stuff that gets jarred up, might as well put it somewhere else


Copied from: https://studio.plugins.atlassian.com/browse/CLMVN-134

When running clover2 plugin (version 3.0+) within a maven build, some instrumentation artifacts are being placed in the main output folder - e.g. <basedir>/target/classes - and are not cleaned up.

At the packaging (and deploy) phase, these leftover instrumentation artifacts are making it into the jar or war file and are getting deployed with the final product - outcome completely undesired.

These instrumentation artifacts are:
  *  *.ser files the main output folder - e.g. target/classes/instrumentation.ser
  *  groverconfig* folders - e.g. target/classes/groverconfig34006
        these folders also contain instrumentation.ser files

*Workaround:*

Delete Clover's files just before packaging. Example:

{code:xml}
<build>
  <plugins>
    <plugin>
      <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
      <artifactId>maven-antrun-plugin</artifactId>
      <version>1.7</version>
      <configuration>
        <target>
          <delete includeemptydirs="true">
            <fileset dir="target">
              <include name="**/instrumentation.ser"/>
              <include name="**/groverconfig*"/>
            </fileset>
          </delete>
        </target>
      </configuration>
      <executions>
        <execution>
          <phase>prepare-package</phase>
          <goals>
            <goal>run</goal>
          </goals>
        </execution>
     </executions>
    </plugin>
  </plugins>
</build>
{code}
fields.summary: serialized instrumentation file being placed in ${project.build.outputDirectory} (target/classes)

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Status as of 15 December 2011|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5| titleBGColor=#3C78B5| bgColor=#E7F4FA}

Hi Folks,

Thanks for your feedback, we regularly review your requests in order to schedule the improvements that our customers highlight as most important and useful.

After surveying the Clover customer base, we believe that the main use cases of Clover are satisfied by its current feature set.  Due to this, we have decided to close this feature request as we are not planning to address this in the near future.  

For any questions or queries, please feel free to comment on this issue, we will get back to you in a timely manner.

Regards,

Josh Devenny
Atlassian Product Management
{panel}


*Status update 18.06.2014:*

I've made a spike for this. It's feasible and I've got a working prototype, but it needs *a lot* of polishing.


*Tasks:*
 (/) perform spike to estimate complexity
 (!) solve problem with concurrent updates of clover.db (first is IDE/JPS builder process for Java code, second is Groovyc AST transformer) - maybe we could use two databases instead and merge them after the build in memory for reporting? it would require change in Settings > Clover window as well
 (x) serialize Clover configuration to instrumentation.ser (initstring etc to be used by Clover Groovy AST Transformer)
 (x) serialize inclusion/exclusion patterns for *.groovy files into the instrumentation.ser (files to be instrumented by Clover)
 (x) integrate with IDEA's Groovy plugin (e.g. via GroovyBuilderExtension)
 (x) pick Clover AST Transformer by groovyc process (META-INF/services)
 (x) handle build started/finished events for Groovy-based projects
 (x) show Groovy classes in the Cloverage view
 (x) handle stub generation by groovyc?
 (x) syntax highlighting for Groovy code (in editor tab)
 (x) check integration with Groovy test runner / Spock test runner
 (x) check instrumentation of mixed Java/Groovy projects (esp. compilation of Java sources from groovyc)
 (x) handle compilation of Groovy code triggered from other IDEA plug-ins, such as: Grails, Gradle, Griffon
 (x) check report generation (HTML, XML, PDF) launched from IDEA

fields.description:
If you have a JUnit test case with some test methods, as well as running tests of another class in a test suite maven will count the number of tests differently to clover. 

!http://img.skitch.com/20100401-guww9dwh3t2y933xkkb62awb6s.jpg!

So there there are two test cases, and we run another 2 tests from the MyTestSuiteTest class. Maven will show this as 4 tests on the DownloadHandlerPerformanceTest test class: 

{noformat}-------------------------------------------------------
 T E S T S
-------------------------------------------------------
Running DownloadHandlerPerformanceTest
Tests run: 4, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 0.088 sec
Running MyTestSuiteTest
Tests run: 2, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 0.006 sec
{noformat}

Whereas clover shows a different result:

!http://img.skitch.com/20100401-j52w9unp7jhdequr9sbtcwsyks.jpg! 

It counts the 2 tests in MyTestSuiteTest with that class rather than DownloadHandlerPerformanceTest. To me this is correct since that is where the tests are defined, but some customers find this confusing and think we should mirror what maven is telling us.
fields.summary: Clover shows a different number of tests cases to maven
